I was on a multi-year streak on Spanish, English and Japanese when I go fed up with the owl. This was after they went public.They put more and more pressure on their users to finish weekly goals with random partners/friends from their friendslists. It didn't feel like working together to achieve something but more like a chore: "I need to do this now or else we won't get that goal and my friend will be disappointed." It felt toxic. So I dropped my multi-year streak to take a Duolingo break.And THEN the AI hammer dropped which broke the camel's back for me. I vented my frustration in Google's app-store, cancelled my account and never went back.I'm still looking for a friendly and human first language app though :(

AI had nothing to do with me leaving after 6 years.It was the change in GUI, removal of cool features and the change from hearts to the battery.the latter was the worst, since you had to watch even more ads, which took time.In the end you may have been learning for 15 minutes, but you were also watching 20 minutes of ads üòÇ

To be honest, I quit duolingo after it became extremely pro-LGBT and forced me to refer to males as females, and to normalize same-sex marriages by doing exercises about lesbians and two husbands. AI just made it worse.

The main reason I deleted Duolingo was because I was sick of the owl gaslighting me. Like, the main tactic of getting me to use Duolingo was it trying to convince me I'm a lazy or bad person for not using it. Then when that failed, it would try to appeal to me with its whole "I miss you!" tactic. App notifications were like getting texts from a manipulative girlfriend/boyfriend.Now, throw AI in there, I can't really imagine why people would still consider it. Token-based or Markov-style algorithms can never be 100% accurate; it's a fundamental baked into that branch of predictive mathematics--it's probables, i.e. "It is probably x with varying confidence intervals." So, yeah, I'm not surprised users are reporting a large drop in quality. People put way too much faith in generative AI without first understanding the fundamentals and/or mathematical principles behind it. Even a model with 99% accuracy--which sound great--is pretty woeful and results in a lot of mistakes that could be anything from minor to critical with no controlling that. Generating a language plan at a very generous 99% would still mean half a million Duolingo users got a defective plan.A moronic thing to base a business on, especially when accuracy/quality is a fundamental requirement of the product's existence.
9:25 I can't believe the CEO actually said this publicly. What a total lack of self-awareness. Amazing

Duolingo was never good. It might be the case that it is worse now, but that should not be a reason to redcon it into this great app that suddenly got ruined with one bad decision.  If you would not know about the shift to AI, would you have noticed the difference? It was always slop. It is a terrible application, gamification is annoying, the sounds and dings and taaaadaahhhs are irksome, there is no pedagogy behind it, it is intolerably boring and it just tries to get people addicted to rewards, streaks and affirming sound effects. It is not teaching you a language, it just turns you into a Pavlovian dog waiting for its reward.

This is why I don't trust companies that have IPOs. There are only laws to protect investors, there are no laws comparable to protect customers in any similar way. There for, the interests to keep investors happy is forced above all else.On top of that, investors can have control over a "Good" company and destroy them if they don't do what the investors tell them to do. Be it sell their 20,000 shares all at once (Crashing the stock hard and immediately which then has a snowball effect), make claims to the government that the company isn't "protecting my assets like the law says they should", or whatever else exists as a weapon that scheming investors do to force investment growth above all else.There are no Governmental protections codified into law that protects companies from Crony Capitalists (if you don't know what that is, it means the evil side of capitalism. Capitalism in itself is not bad, it's people that take advantage of good people that make it look as bad as it does to some). They can do all of these tricks and schemes to force compliance from these companies into whatever they tell them to do, or the companies go under fighting against the investor's whims.If we could have laws that protected companies (Only to an extent) that read somewhere along the line of, "If investor ideas run the risk of damaging the company outright, Going against said investors does not breach Investor integrity laws. By a company denying "advised actions" given to them by investors occur, the investors cannot pull more than 10% of there held stocks at any given moment or within the next 300 days. If they are threatening to sell all of their stock, or their is a suspicion that they may to damage the company, the company has the right to sue the investor for their stocks back in which they will purchase them back for a fair (Either agreed upon or court ordered) price and doing so will also ban the individual or entity the right to buy stocks from that IPO in the future for no less than 10 years."It's a very basic idea that i've had for a while, but for many some-what "good" companies that still kinda give a crap about their reputation with their customers, it would be a defense against malicious actors that don't care if the company survives longer than 5 years or not after their initial IPO open. With some protections for the companies, they would have a leg to stand on if they say no rapid growth that would destroy the company in the near future.

Duo used to be fun and learning was productive.  Now they have gamified the whole program.  If I want to play games I will go to a game site.  I want to learn Italian.  I am not in competition with anyone else.  I am competing with myself and challenging myself to be better.  "Energy" has ruined the program.  There are times when I cannot even finish one lesson because I run out of "energy".  And I have reached a score of 60, but have not advanced in the last 6 months because I have not had any new lessons.  Same old stuff.  While their stories were fine the first couple of times, by the 100th time they are no longer fun or interesting. I can almost repeat every line by heart.   Same old stuff.  Same old stuff.  I'm tired of the same old stuff.  I am just a few days from completing a 1,600 day streak. I have decided that I will go until the end of the year and then it's good-bye to the same old stuff.  Paying to get rid of advertisements and then still getting the same old stuff.  If I want to pay I will go to a better program to advance my Italian.   Ciao Duo.

It really didn't bother me that they were gonna use AI, considering that the AI part was just the voices of the characters in the app. What really made my view of them much worse than before is putting useful stuff behind a paywall. Before they had hearts that actually made you to be weary and aware of what you learn, and you could replenish them by doing practices. It was tedious but nevertheless, made you practice with it. Now they completely removed that. You can't practice to earn more hearts anymore, and a health bar every time you answer a question depletes. This is just plain greedy at this point. For Duolingo to be actually useful, you have to buy their subscription.
